questions.text: A 11-month-old child presented with recurrent abdominal pain. On examination a mass can be felt in lumbar region. A barium enema study was done. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into itself or a neighboring loop of the bowel by peristalsis. The classic triad of intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and right upper quadrant mass, plus occult or gross blood on rectal examination. A contrast enema remains the gold standard, demonstrating the intussusception as an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, giving the "coiled spring" appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space).

On usg - Target /Doughnut sign is seen.


KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • claw sign/pincer clasp/coiled spring appearance is seen on Barium enema.
  • Target /Doughnut sign is seen on usg.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1144

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital obstruction of the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) is a common anomaly of the urinary tract.

The proposed etiology includes incomplete recanalization of the ureter during early gestation, aberrant vessel causing extrinsic compression, or other bands/kinks causing PUJ constriction.

Dilated renal pelvis and calyces are demonstrated on urography. Delayed radiographs are usually necessary for demonstrating the point of obstruction at UPJ. With longstanding or high-grade obstruction the kidney may become nonfunctional. When there is insufficient contrast excretion or the ureter is not visualized, the diagnosis can be established by antegrade pyelography.

The given image shows hydronephrotic kidney with abrupt transition to ureter. This is suggestive of PUJ obstruction.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 23

questions.text: A 22 year old female with primary infertility underwent HSG examination and shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given HSG image shows septate uterus with narrow intercornual angle.
  • Septate uterus- The intercornual angle is less than 75° and the intercornual distance is less than 4cm.
  • Bicornuate Uterus- The intercornual angle is more than 105° and the intercornual distance is more than 4cm.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 297

questions.text: A middle aged male patient presented with acute onset pain in right limb. An investigation was performed. What is the name of the investigation?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography with color Doppler is another modality which can be of use in the evaluation of PVD. Apart from the grayscale (B mode), Doppler principle can be used to overlay color and generate graphical spectrum of the flow dynamics. Normal extremity artery shows a triphasic high resistance flow pattern with a preserved spectral window.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Triphasic pattern in seen in arterial doppler

Monophonic pattern is seen venous doppler

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2699.

questions.text: A 35 year old female presented with fever, expectoration and difficulty breathing. HRCT of chest was performed and shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Consolidation is characterized by abnormal dense opacification of the lung parenchyma with obscuration of the underlying vessels. It may be alveolar or interstitial in origin, though most commonly the alveolar air is replaced by fluid, cells, tissue or pus. On HRCT, consolidation results in an increase in lung opacity with underlying vessels being obscured. Air bronchogram are usually seen if the bronchi are patent.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2370
Question ID: 1215954

questions.text: Name the investigation shown
questions.solution:
The given image shows PET CT of patient.

A positron emission tomography ( PET) scan is an imaging test that can help reveal the metabolic or biochemical function of the tissues and organs. It uses a radioactive drug called tracer and can often detect the atypical metabolism of the tracer in diseases before it shows up on other imaging tests. PET-CT is a unique combination of crosssectional anatomic information provided by CT and the metabolic information provided by PET which are acquired during a single examination and fused.

The major source of energy in neurons is glucose ,while in PET-CT 18 FDG glucose is used. Therefore we can see increased uptake in the brain.

Cortex of bone is appearing white indicating it is CT.

If bone cortex appears black with increased uptake in the brain then it is suggestive of PET MRI.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 3844

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of saccular aneurysm in brain?
questions.solution:
The subarachnoid spaces (SASs) are CSF-filled cavities that lie between the arachnoid and the pia. Hemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).. Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular hemorrhage. The typical location of SAH (basal cisterns and sylvian and inferior interhemispheric fissures). The gross appearance of a SAH is typically characterized by blood-filled basal cisterns. Rupture of an aneurysm typically leads to SAH.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Mc cause of subarachnoid Hemorrhage is Trauma.

Mc cause of spontaneous subarachnoid Hemorrhage is rupture of berry aneurysm.

IOC for SAH- NCCT

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 Brain edition 2 pg 123

choices.text: Isolated osteoma of floor of mouth

questions.text: A 45 year old patient complains of recurrent swelling in one side of the neck. She is afraid of eating food as it worsens the swelling. Imaging was performed and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a radiopaque material in the mandibular region which is suggestive of sialolithasis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology pg 3771

questions.text: A 30 year old patient presented to the causality after a motor vehicle accident. He has bruises on the chest. His pulse is l00bpm. BP is 140/85and RR is 28. A chest X ray was performed and shown below. What is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient
questions.solution:
This is a case of Tension pneumothorax, a life-threatening condition that occurs when air enters the pleural space and becomes trapped, causing pressure to build up. This pressure can compress the lung and shift the trachea leading to severe respiratory distress and even death.

X ray findings of Tension pneumothorax:

  • Hyperlucency: The affected side of the chest will appear darker than the other side, indicating increased air density.
  • Mediastinal shift: The mediastinum (the area between the lungs that contains the heart, major blood vessels, and trachea) will be shifted away from the affected side.
  • Rib spreading: The ribs on the affected side may appear more widely spaced.
  • Tracheal deviation: The trachea may be deviated away from the affected side.
  • Absent lung markings: The lung on the affected side may appear collapsed and have no visible lung markings.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema: This is a condition in which air leaks into the tissues under the skin, causing a crackling sensation

Management- placement of wide bore needle followed by chest tube insertion.


Reference: MacDuff A, Arnold A, Harvey JManagement of spontaneous pneumothorax: British Thoracic Society pleural disease guideline 2010 Thorax 2010;65:ii l 8-ii3l.

questions.text: A 35 year old patient presented with severe abdominal pain and vomiting? His vitals are stable. What is the most effective way to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
Gas under the diaphragm is a sign of perforation of the viscera. It is an emergency condition and would require patient stabilization with iv fluid and further exploratory laparotomy to find the cause of perforation and seal it.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2080

questions.text: A 25 year old patient presented with fever, dry cough, breathlessness and night sweats. On chest X-ray, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy was seen. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Sarcoidosis is a chronic, multisystem disease of unknown etiology characterized pathologically by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. Hilar adenopathy is easily recognized on radiographs. Garland triad/1-2-3 sign/ Pawnbrokers sign, is the characteristic nodal involvement at the right paratracheal and bilateral hilar groups which may be identified on radiography.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no pg 2385

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented with a pulsatile supraclavicular neck mass. What is the most appropriate next investigation?
questions.solution:
A pulsatile mass suggests a vascular etiology, such as:

  • Subclavian artery aneurysm
  • Carotid body tumor
  • Arteriovenous fistula

Doppler Ultrasound (USG) is the first-line investigation as it is non-invasive, quick, and helps assess vascular structures, flow characteristics, and potential thrombosis.

Other Options:

  • (B) CT Angiography + Percutaneous Intervention:
    • CT Angio is useful after an initial Doppler confirms a vascular lesion.
    • Intervention is planned after diagnosis, not as a first step.
  • (C) Oral Antibiotics x 7 days:
    • No evidence of infection.
    • Vascular masses are not treated with empiric antibiotics.
  • (D) Needle Biopsy:
    • Contraindicated in vascular lesions (risk of hemorrhage).
    • Biopsy is considered only for non-vascular tumors after vascular etiology is ruled out

Reference: Christensen's Physics of diagnostic radiology page pg 353

questions.text: Prenatal USG in a 35 year old female showed a fetus with multiple fractures. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) refers to a heterogeneous group of congenital, non-sex-linked, genetic disorders of collagen type I production, involving connective tissues and bones.

The hallmark feature of osteogenesis imperfecta is osteoporosis and fragile bones that fracture easily, as well as, blue sclera, dental fragility and hearing loss.

The radiographic features are as follows:

Head, neck and spine

  • Basilar invagination
  • Wormian bones
  • Kyphoscoliosis
  • Vertebral compression fractures
  • Codfish vertebrae
  • Platyspondyly

Chest

  • Pectus excavatum or carinatum
  • Accordion ribs

Pelvis

  • Protrusio acetabuli
  • Coxa vara

General

  • Severe osteoporosis
  • Deformed, gracile (overtubulated) bones
  • Cortical thinning
  • Hyperplastic callus formation
  • Popcorn calcification: the metaphyses and epiphyses exhibit numerous scalloped radiolucent areas with sclerotic margins
  • Zebra stripe sign: cyclic bisphosphonate treatment produces sclerotic growth recovery lines in the long bones
  • Formation of pseudarthrosis at sites of healing fractures

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1338

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Enchondromas, also known as chondromas, are relatively common intramedullary cartilage neoplasms with benign imaging features. Enchondromas have a variable appearance, although typically they are small <5 cm lytic lesions with non-aggressive features:

  • Narrow zone of transition
  • Sharply defined margins
  • +/- Chondroid calcification (rings and arcs calcification)
    • Often no matrix mineralization (purely lytic) in the hands/feet
  • +/- Expansile
    • More commonly in hands/feet
    • May have mild endosteal scalloping
    • Should not 'grow' through cortex (unless a pathological fracture)

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2921
